awd_titl_txt: Small CIF: Coding and Detection for Two-dimensional Magnetic Recording Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic recording is the most widely used technology for reliably storing digital information. A stored bit is physically realized as a collection of tiny magnetic grains magnetized to one of two stable polarities. This project relies on a new paradigm of two-dimensional magnetic recording, which exploits a small number of grains to store one bit as well as two-dimensional coding of user data combined with signal detection to ensure reliable storage and retrieval of information.

The project addresses the main challenge in two-dimensional magnetic recording which arises due to the fact that grains are irregularly shaped and randomly positioned on the media surface, and hence, the signal read back is dominated by noise due to this random granularity of the medium. The project develops novel data recovery algorithms capable of compensating such high noise levels. These algorithms are based on advanced information theory and coding theory concepts, namely, constrained codes, probabilistic graphical models, and iterative detection and decoding.  A two-dimensional constraint is viewed as a colored tiling of a plane, which affords using the rich theory of planar gas models from statistical mechanics and the theory of domino and lozenge tilings from combinatorics. On the detection front, the project develops generalized belief propagation and linear programming algorithms for dealing with the large number of loops in two-dimensional magnetic recording graphical models.

In light of the tremendous growth of the amount of digital data created, processed and stored, it is vitally important to ensure the continued rapid increases in capacity of magnetic hard disk drives.  The project is concerned with a new technology that has the potential to increase hard drive capacity by an order of magnitude.  Signal processing methods for improving storage capacity developed in this project have a crucial role in providing a foundation for development of future storage systems.  They provide not only a new standard of performance in the area of data storage, but have a direct impact on the performance capabilities of a new generation of computers, data networks and services provided on the internet.

por.por_cntn:
By 2020, the digital universe is estimated to be an unwieldy 44 trillion gigabytes. For example, US data centers currently consume a staggering 2% of the total electrical energy, and data storage accounts for more than 25% of the energy used by data centers. If energy efficiency is not improved, by 2020 the US will require 17 new power plants just for data centers. Magnetic recording is the most widely used technology for reliably storing digital information. A stored bit is physically realized as a collection of tiny ferromagnetic grains magnetized to one of the two stable polarities. Over the past sixty years, a sustained increase in storage density has been achieved primarily through innovations in media design, leading to hard disks with density of over 1 Tb/ , data transfer rates exceeding 6 Gb/s, and bit error rates as low as 1010−1015. The demand for high densities has pushed grain size to its fundamental limit dictated by the grain thermal instability, and has created the need for innovations towards new recording technologies such as, heat/energy assisted magnetic recording (HAMR), bit patterned media (BPM), and two-dimensional magnetic recording (TDMR).

 

TDMR is an emerging storage technology that aims to achieve areal densities about 10 Tb/  mainly driven by innovative channels engineering with minimal changes to existing head/media designs within a systems framework. Significant additive areal density gains can be achieved using TDMR over BPM and energy assisted magnetic recording (EAMR). In TDMR, the sectors are inherently two-dimensional with reduced track pitch and bit widths, leading to severe 2D inter-symbol interference (ISI). This necessitates the development of powerful two-dimensional signal processing and coding algorithms for mitigating 2D ISI, jitter noise due to irregular media grain positions and electronics noise during reading towards a read-write channel architecture on a system-on-chip (SoC) within a disk controller system.

 

One of the main outcomes of this project was channel modeling at the read/write and media levels. Modeling is an important aspect in any practical engineering system since we need to abstract the physical reality in a mathematically tractable manner. In the TDMR context, a spatial point process can approximate the distribution of magnetic grains with varying shapes and sizes. We have described various models that capture the grain size and distribution over bit cell boundaries along with physical parameters such as the bit size, bit aspect ratio etc. in parametric form. Coded information bits are written onto the medium and bi-polarly magnetized within and around the bit boundaries. The read-back signal from the medium suffers from cross talk due to neighboring bit cells when filtered through bandlimited read heads along with media and electronics noise. In order to compensate these artifacts, we have devised advanced coding and signal processing techniques with relevant channel models and a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) metric towards benchmarking the algorithms for TDMR systems. Moreover, from the modeling results, we have estimated areal densities along with system level optimization based on physical parameters for maximizing areal density gains. We also have provided a thorough treatment on generalized partial response equalization, noise predictive signal detection techniques within a two-dimensional channels framework over the TDMR media models.

Channel codes such as modulation codes and error correcting codes (ECC) are an integral part of a read-write channel in most of data storage systems. Modulation codes are used for shaping the coded spectrum to better match the channel constraints as well as satisfy certain constraints to reduce the effect of 2D ISI. The design of efficient 2D modulation codes is a challenging problem since computing the capacity of 2D modulation constraints is a well-known difficult problem, unsolved yet, in exact form. We have proposed and examined different 2D modulation codes applicable to TDMR channels. These constraints are chosen based on empirical evidence from the Voronoi media model. We also have used graph-based codes that are especially well suited for TDMR systems and evaluated the efficacy of the coded system to assess areal density gains.

 

Our research in improving storage capacity of TDMR had a vital role in providing a foundation for development of future storage systems. The effort was coordinated with researchers from both academia and industry involved in projects funded by International Disk Drive Equipment and Materials Association (IDEMA), addressing other aspects of 2D magnetic recording. Three graduate students have been involved in this project. The students have received broad training in mathematics, science, and engineering, and have successful careers in both academia in industry. The PI has given several lectures to Native American high school students at the Tohono O’odham Nation reservation.
